As promised, I’m posting my solutions to the magnet riddle and looking through your solutions (holy moly, lots of comments.) Breaking the magnet in half could work! But there’s the possibility of demagnetizing the metal by hitting it too hard. (It’s possible to MANGETIZE some metals by hitting them hard in a strong external magnetic field and DEMAGNETIZE them by hitting them hard. I don’t know how hard…) So I’d break bar A, test whether it sticks to bar B, if it does, then break bar B, and try sticking the A pieces to themselves and the B pieces to themselves. If none of them sticks, it was bar B. If A or B sticks to its own half, it’s that one.

Other solutions I thought of that may or may not work: Similar to above, hitting the bars one by one and seeing whether they still stick (also thought up by Banane Dollar and others). Shaving off some pieces of iron, and seeing which bar they stick to. (alsothought up by +Wynchesster and many others) Moving a loop of wire connected to an ammeter near the magnet to see whether any current is produced. (If so that’s the magnet.)

Ruven Pinkhasov thought of the traditional (and my fav) solution to this riddle because it uses NO tools: move the bars orthogonal to each other forming a T shape. The non-magnet will feel a change along the length of the magnet, which have a weaker pulling the middle, and stronger toward the ends. This solution assumes the bars have a simple long-ways N-S configuration, but no matter the magnetization configuration, this method could work somehow. Also pros to Krekker Recer, Nipun Wahi and others!

Ravi Sharma thought of hanging the bars from a string and seeing which aligns with earth’s magnetic field. I don’t know if this would work in practice because it depends on the strength of the bar’s magnetization and the weight of the bars relative to torsional forces in the string. But in theory, it should work with a strong enough magnet in a strong enough external magnetic field. Props to Dan Kennedy, Abi Rozario and others for thinking of this.

Adam Pearce, TANGENT PROPELLER and Kenny Maccormac and others would try heating the bars, then touching them (presumably after they've cooled again?) to see which one becomes unmagnetized after heating. They’d have to get pretty hot: beyond the Curie temperature of iron

Creativity award goes to Valtteri Huuskonen who would use a phone manometer. Borderline cheating…

Thanks for SO many comments answering the riddles! If you have suggestions for other riddle guests, best to leave them in a channel comment. They’ll likely get lost here at this point.

Aluminum, Stainless Steel , Bronze, Copper, Lead, Gold, Silver, Brass, Platinum and Zinc. These are all Non-Magnetic Metals. However, when a magnet moves close to some of them, it causes an electrical field, which interacts with these metals. This is called Lenz’s Law, after Emil Lenz, a renowned physicist. The interaction here is best shown by dropping a powerful magnet down a thick aluminum tube. The magnet will fall incredibly slowly as it experiences interference from the electrical fields created by its movement :)

If you have a bar magnet and an identically-shaped bar of iron that is indistinguishable aside from the magnetic properties, then I'd take the end of one and touch it near the middle of the other. Then I would separate them and do the same using the other one.

The magnetic field is weak in the middle of a magnet, while strong at the ends. If you put the end of a magnet near the middle of a bar of iron, it would attract it with the same force as if it was drawn to the end of the iron. But if you put the end of a piece of iron near the center of a bar magnet, there will be very little attraction. It will be stronger at the ends. So to confirm it, I would take whatever piece I believe to be the bar of iron and try to hold it close to the magnet, running it from roughly one end to the other, feeling the stronger pull at each end, and weaker in the middle.

You don't need to break the bars for the magnet riddle. In fact, you don't even need to use any tool in the room but the bars themselves. You just make a "T" configuration with the bars (lying on the floor): if the "vertical" segment of the T is the magnetized bar, then the barycenter of the "horizontal" (non magnetized) bar will feel a force pushing it towards the barycenter of the other bar; if the "horizontal" segment of the T is the magnetized bar, the barycenter of other segment will not feel pushed towards the barycenter of other bar, but laterally.

Your iron breaking theory is in reality, pure fiction. Having worked in engineering for 30 years I know iron bars can't be broken with a non-ferrous hammer. Assuming it's not hardened you might bend it a bit if it's thin but unless it's made of cast iron (i.e. has no grain structure) and is also thin you can't break an iron bar with a non-ferrous hammer no matter how hard you hit it. Simple experiment to prove it using a method at the opposite end of the scale.....get a metal knife and smash it many many times with a 14 pound sledge hammer.... nope it doesn't break. About the only way an iron bar would break with a hammer is if it was hardened to 60RC and then you hit it with a big heavy hammer, it might break after whacking it a few times. Or if it was cast iron it might break. Also, note most specially shaped magnets ARE cast and are brittle so hitting the magnet (if it was a cast type) would break it into many pieces, not just in half. Having said all of that, it was still an interesting few minutes.... most people watching this are more than likely male and just here because they have time to waste and you are smoking hot ;-)

It's been a while since I played with rectangular magnets, but it should be pretty simple without breaking anything. One is a permanent magnet, and the other becomes temporarily magnetised when the permanent magnet comes close. For a permanent magnet, the magnetic field is strongest at the poles and weakest in the middle, whereas the temporary magnet has poles always facing towards the poles of the other one. The upshot is, you hold them both tight, and bring them close in three different different configurations to determine which is the temporary magnet.

First, bring them together and let them attract each other and stick to each other; you are guaranteed that the pole of one is on one of the faces of the magnets. Then pull them apart slightly, holding tight. First, rotate the left one 90 degrees and feel the difference in force, then return it to it's original position and do the same with the right one.

When you rotate the temporary magnet, you should feel equal force attracting it to the pole, because the induced pole will always be towards the permanent pole. When you rotate the permanent magnet, the other bar is being placed further away from both of the poles and hence should result in a lesser force attracting it, and you should feel less force pulling them together.

How about sticking the two bars together in such a way that they make a "T" shape, i.e. one touching the other in the middle of the first one. If the "roof" of the T is the (permanent) magnet, the force will be weak (and in an idealized situation, if using very thin bars, equal almost to zero), whereas if the "roof" of the T is the soft magnetic bar (or as you call it the "non-magnet"), the force of attraction will be much stronger.

BTW: The VAST MAJORITY of metals is not ferromagnetic, only a few, like Fe, Ni, and Co are, with some other rare earth elements/metals also thrown in (like Dy, Gd, Dy, at low enough T), and a few weird alloys, like MnBi or MnSb. So your mallet could be made from many metals, tungsten, uranium, bronze or brass, etc. etc. I noticed some hesitation about that, before you chose "rock" as your preferred mallet material...

I'm a little late to the game, but I don't think I see anything like this in the comments I've scanned so far:

Take two sheets of paper out of the office drawer. Use the diamond file to scrape some filings off of bar 1 and bar 2, putting them onto separate sheets of paper. Put bar 2 under bar 1's filings, and vice versa. Whichever bar is magnetized should draw the non-magnetized filings into a flux pattern on that piece of paper, while on the other sheet, the magnetized filings will simply be drawn into a rectangular cluster over the non-magnetized bar.

Any end of the magnet would be attracted strongly to the center of the non-magnet. Any end of the non-magnet would be attracted weakly to the center of the magnet. You therefore have an asymmetry that distinguishes the magnet from the non-magnet.

Assuming there is some sort of conducting metal in the room, you could suspend both of these bars above the metal with a string, pull it back to act as a pendulum. Count the number of oscillations until it slows to half its original amplitude. The magnet will always slow down faster than the iron bar will because it will create eddy currents in the conducting metal which will cause an opposing magnetic field to slow the magnet. This effect acts a little like friction that only applies to the magnet.

For the magnet riddle, I suggest to put the 2 iron bars together so that they form a ''T'' shape. With that arrangement, the force of attraction between the 2 will be different depending on where the magnet is. If the magnet is on top (of the T shape), it won't attract the unmagnetized bar a lot since it's right in between the poles. But if the magnet is on the bottom, it will attract the unmagnetized bar on top like any other piece of iron since it's right on the pole of the magnet.

Lay the 2 bars close to each other, but 1 is perpendicular to the other. Now move the "cross" bar slowly closer so they lie end near end, but at 90°. At some  point they will snap together. Make a note of the distance at which this happens. now repeat the experiment, but move the crossing bar so the other bar will snap at the mid point once the magnetic attraction is great enough.  Make a note of the second distance.  If the distances are equal, the crossing bar is non-magnetic, if the second distance is shorter, the crossing bar is magnetic.  Since the magnetic field flows around from pole to pole, the mid point of the magnet is a bit weaker.  Of course, you can also file some shavings from either bar and see the magnetic flow lines. But that requires more work, and I'm lazy...

Without any tools you can solve it by rubbing one bar on the other in one direction over and over. You can then tell what each bar is by seeing how it reacts.

Case 1 the bar you pick up is the magnet:
The magnet will align the spins of the electrons in the bar, making it a temporary magnet. Then hold it to different parts of the magnet. You can then see that the formerly nonmagnetized bar repels the bar in your hand, meaning that the one in your hand was the magnet all along.

Case 2 you end up picking up the nonmagnet :

Since only part of the bar in your hand is touching the magnet, the electrons throughout the bar stay the same, so when you do the same test as above, you won't see any repulsion. This means that the bar in your hand is the nonmagnet.

You may try dropping them next to a filing cabinet. Filing cabinets are usually made of a metal. As the magenet is moving downwards next to the wall of the cabinet, it will induce a current in the metal wall. The magnetic filed of this current will slow down the drop of the magnet. You may also try creating a similar effect with the hammer. The head of the hammer is usualli also made of a metal. Siwinging it next to a megnet, induces a current in the metal. My answer:

Choose one of the bars at random (bar A). Align the bar A with the other one (bar B) perpendicularly (like a T). Swipe bar A in one direction repeatedly for a while. One of 2 things will happen: if bar A is the magnet, bar B will become magnetised; if bar A is not the magnet, bar B will not become magnetised.
Now simply place bar A and bar B near each other and rotate bar A slowly until you see/feel it repel bar B. If this happens, then bar A is the magnet. If not bar B is the magnet.

Hey!! I've got a different solution.. no need of using any of the props she's provided.
1. Let's name the two rods A and B.
2. Let's say we throw A on the floor a LOT of times.
3. Then we bring A and B close to each other.
4. (i) If A and B do not attract- A is the magnetised one as it has lost its magnetic field after hitting the floor several times.
(ii) If A and B attract but with a lesser force- A is the magnetised one and its magnetic field has got weaker for the same reason.
(iii) If A and B attract with the same force- B is the magnetised one for obvious reasons.

PS- if we get the (iii) results, we must not jump to conclusions though, and maybe try step 2. a several more times and check the results.

For the "challenge question", I think the answer is what I initially thought, tie the iron bar to the string, and suspend them and hope one points to the magnetic north pole. Alternatively, since there's a filing cabinet, and since filing cabinets are made of metal, but we're assuming this metal is non magnetic, since the filing cabinet is made of metal, it should be able to conduct electricity well. This can be exploited by tilting the filing cabinet against say a wall, such that there is a slope for the magnets to slide on. Then, because of Lenz's law (moving magnets induce currents in metal which oppose the magnetic field of said magnet), one iron bar will slide down the filing cabinet much slower than the other. The one that slides slower is the magnetized one

1) You should be able to determine the magnet by holding the bars in a T-conformation. The magnetic field is weakest in the center of the magnet (but strongest at the end). Now switch the bars placements and see which T gave the best hold.

I can think of 3 solutions:
1) Use the file to file some fine iron dust (from bar #1). Magnetic dust will clump together, non magnetic dust will act like dust. If that doesn't work (let's say filing caused the metal to heat and lose it's magnetic properties) you can sprinkle the dust near the bars, the magnetic bar will push the dust into the magnetic field lines (maybe shake the working surface a little by tapping it with the mallet). This is by far the easiest solution.
2) Suspend the bars from a string and let them naturally come to a rest. assuming the 2 bars are far away from each other, one of them will orient itself towards the magnetic north. As someone who tried to improvise compasses before - this one is extremely tricky, and might take many attempts to get right.
3) Assuming the mallet / the file are made of non-magnetic metal (and not ceramic / rubber etc.) - you can suspend one of the bars on a string and twist it a few hundred times. Then place the mallet near the bar and let go of the string. A spinning magnet will induce an electric current through metallic objects the bar will come to a rest slightly faster if it is magnetized. We might also see a slight heating due to the electric current. This solution is a theoretical one, I highly doubt it will create any noticeable difference (especially without any precise measuring device).

My solutions to the magnetic bar riddle.
1- Using Earth's magnetic field: use the string to create a compass.
2- Use the objects geometry: touch the bars with different orientations, and notice any asymmetry in the magnetic force. If a magnetized bar's point is touching a regular bar's middle, the force should be weaker than a magnetized bar's middle touching a regular bar's point.
3- Try to demagnetize one of the bars: hit it hard with a mallet! If nothing happens, it was already non-magnetic. If the force weakens, that was a previously magnetic bar.

It's easy, since magnets aren't perfectly homogenous fields they have different strengths at various points between their poles. You hold the two bars side by side and within the field. Then you keep one still and pitch the other. If the moving bar does not tug the stationary bar, the stationary bar is the magnet. You are looking to pitch the ferrous bar inside the magnetic field, because the magnet's field won't be moving; but if you pitch the magnet near the bar, the field strength will change and tug differently on the ferrous bar based on its field's pitch. (The field is stronger at the poles, if you aim a pole at the bar and wiggle it, you can feel it pulling on the bar.)

The magnet has a north pole and a south pole. When you place the bars perpendicular to each other (to form a "T") such that the end of the non-magnetized bar is touching the magnet near its center between the poles, the polar forces will cancel and the net magnetic attraction will be at its weakest. As you move the iron slightly off-center toward a pole, the magnet will tend to want to flip to line up end to end with the iron bar.
If, instead, it is the end of the magnet that is touching the center of the non-magnetized bar, the attraction will be as strong as ever and sliding it a little toward one end of the iron bar won't cause much change. With a little manipulation, it is thus a simple task to distinguish the magnet from the non-magnet.

A relatively infeasible one that uses nothing but the bars: Take each bar and toss them in the air many, many times, recording the angles at which they land. If one is more likely to be aligned in one direction than the other, that's the magnetic bar.

A really cool one that is even less feasible: If there's a metal pipe nearby that's large enough to drop the bars down, do it. The magnetized bar will take longer than expected, due to eddy currents induced in the pipe! The material of the pipe doesn't even need to be magnetic, it just needs to be a conductor. Possible solution:
Try putting the two bars in a "T" shape. If it sticks nicely in a "T", the bottom (vertical) one is the magnet. If the bottom one tries to off-center itself (forming a "7"), the top one is the magnet.

Explanation: bar magnets have a North and South pole, and the magnetic field is stronger at either end of the magnet. Therefore, things that are magnetized are drawn towards the ends more strongly than the center. In a "T" shape, the end of one is coming in contact with the center of the other; if the bottom one is the magnet, the normal iron is already touching the magnet's pole and will stay put. However, if the top one is the magnet, the iron is touching its center, so it will be drawn towards one end (the pole).

Two immediate tests come to mind.
1; Align them into a perpendicular T that's not touching each other and slide the lower bar up until it magnetizes with the other. Repeat with the bars in vise versa. The magnet is the one that has the stronger pull to the middle of the other bar.

My answer to the magnet problem:
As the magnet has to have to poles where the attraction the strongest, there is a lot less attraction in the middle. So if you arrange both iron bars in a T-shape, they will only attract if the lower one is the magnet, otherwise, if the magnetic one is on top of the T, there would be no attraction at all. The force between the bars depends on how they point, in a different way for the magnet and the iron. Let's look at the simplest bar shape, a square. All four sides of the iron square are the same. The force between it and the magnet is the same (at some distance) regardless of which side faces the magnet. Now think of the square magnet. Two of its sides are pole faces and two aren't. The force depends on whether a pole face or a non-pole face is facing the iron.

For elongated bars, unfortunately even for the plain iron the force depends on whether the long direction or the short direction faces the magnet. So figuring out the quantitative difference in how the force depends on which way the iron points and which way the magnet points requires some calculation, which we're too lazy to do.

You should be able to do this without anything other than the pieces of iron themselves. We all know the shape of the field lines surrounding a magnet, and how the density of the field lines at each point corresponds to the strength of the magnetic field at that point.

Imagine holding the non-magnet in your hand, and moving it towards various parts of the magnet. The non-magnet will be more strongly attracted to the poles of the magnet than it will be to the centre of the magnet.

Conversely, imagine holding the magnet in your hand and moving it towards various parts of the non-magnet. The force it feels will be independent of the part that you are moving it towards.

Observing this different behaviour will allow you to work out which bar you are holding!

From what I remember, bar magnets are weakest in the middle (where the majority of the field lines are internal) and strongest at the poles. If you are holding the two bars in both of your hands, you can perform the quick experiment needing nothing else. Hold the end of the bar in your left hand to the middle of the bar in your right hand and take note of how much strength it takes to separate the bars. Now reverse the experiment, holding the end of the bar in your right hand to the middle of the bar in your left and take note if it took more or less force than before. Whatever bar took more force to separate from the center of the other is the magnetic one.

Magnetic flux will be concentrated near the poles of the magnetized bar. So long as they're touched or manipulated like mirror images, the identity of the magnetic bar will remain much a mystery. But you'll be able to find the direction of the magnetic orientation (down the length or across thickness, etc).

Next, touch a suspected pole to the other bar's suspected "anti-pole" or some midpoint between poles (like a T shape). Repeat with them swapped and compare the experiences of pulling them apart.

The magnetized bar will pull harder than the other in this configuration since that pole will be oriented towards the neutral bar.

If they're strongly magnetized, then you could put one on the ground and vigorously wave the other around above it for a minute or two. The magnetized bar would induce fluctuating currents in the other bar, and with enough time, you would be able to feel than one bar is slightly warmer than the other - that one must be unmagnetized. The warmth would be a result of resistance in the bar to the rapidly changing currents.

Faraday's law of induction indicates that if a conductor is exposed to a changing magnetic field, an electromotive force is generated. Hook bar A to a voltmeter, then quickly move bar B over it.
If A's the non-magnetised conductor (and B is the magnetised conductor,) the exposure to an increasing (when B's moved close) then decreasing (when B's moved away) magnetic field creates electromotive force which would be registered on the voltmeter.
If A's the magnetised conductor (and B is the non-magnetised conductor,) then moving B close then far away would not generate a changing magnetic field near A, so no electromotive force would be generated, therefore nothing would be registered.
tl;dr: The non-magnetised conductor registers an increase in voltage on a voltmeter when the magnetised conductor's moved quickly, near it.
